Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Situation2: They interact warmly with a long line of shoppers during a busy lunch hour.
Story: I glanced at my phone during my break, a text from my husband lighting up the screen: “Laundry’s still sitting in the basket. Can you fold it tonight?” I sighed, picturing the mountain of clothes waiting at home, the silent expectation that I’d take care of it after my shift. But as the lunch rush hit, I was back behind the register, pasting on a smile for the endless line of customers. “Hi there! How’s your day going?” I chirped, even as my mind wandered to the chores piling up at home. Each customer expected warmth and patience, but my thoughts kept drifting—would I have the energy to fold laundry after standing all day? My husband wanted a partner who shared the load, but my manager needed a cashier who never let stress show. I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of home and work pressing on my shoulders, wondering how I could possibly meet everyone’s needs.
